text.value: Artificial intelligence is transforming the world[a][b]: how we travel, how we communicate, and how we live. But the AI researchers building these tools aren’t working from scratch. These capabilities take inspiration from how brains learn new things.

btn.text: How do we learn to recognize a scene?
How do we learn to recognize a piece of music?

text.value: Almost half of our brain is devoted to the visual system. Computer vision, the area of AI that deals with how machines see the world, is getting some of the most interest (and funding). To understand how a self-driving car processes a street scene you first need to understand how we see.

visual.title: How does your brain decode a scene?

text.value: After light enters the retina, the scene in front of you is sent from simple visual regions near your eye to more complex ones further into your brain. There is debate in the neuroscience community, but it is likely that early brain systems respond to edges, with single neurons are likely noticing individual edges. This happens even if its a low-contrast situation like a gray car on an overcast evening.
At this point, it’s almost impossible for either a human or a machine to recognize what’s in this scene.
From there, some of the 140 million neurons in the visual system start to share and combine different edges to get basic features, like shapes.
Notice how these simple shapes are some of the earliest children learn to name. This is part of the reason why.

After decoding edges and shapes, more complicated aspects like the orientation of objects and their spatial relationships start to become clear. We’ve added a second oval, but it’s still tough to guess what’s in the scene.
Notice how your brain starts seeing shapes in relation to each other.

What first looked like an oval now looks like two circles in perspective. Your brain uses a sense of depth and space to help turn a collection of objects into a scene. Here are a few more shapes in a scene.
Can you guess what you’re looking at?

Your brain has recurrent connections, continuously sending new information back to previous systems. By comparing what you see to what you’ve seen before, you build an understanding of the world. Computer vision also improves by taking feedback and applying it earlier layers of the algorithm.
Now can you guess what’s in this scene?

Different pathways in your brain light up for scenes than objects, and faces get their own dedicated space in the visual cortex. There might even be neurons that get excited for certain familiar faces, whether a loved one of a celebrity.
Can you guess what’s in this scene?
Finally, the eyes and AI take in the whole scene. This is all happening in about 200 milliseconds and without any perceived effort by the viewer. Computers take a little longer, but not much.

text.value: Computers can also be tricked by things that would never confuse a human eye, like stickers on a stop sign. It’s a major complication that needs to be solved before autonomous vehicles are safe.

When we listen to someone speak, our brains make educated guesses about what’s coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict what words you’ll text next on your phone.

speech.title: This word could save your life

text.value: For our ancestors to adapt and survive, our brain had to establish the relationship between sensory events, like the sounds of speech. And being able to make a guess about what comes next could save precious seconds in life or death situations. To do that, specific neurons in our auditory cortex respond to different phonemes, the smallest units of sound that distinguish one word from another. In English, there are 44 phonemes, like “w” and “f” and “t.”
It’s hard to pick the “right” word without context.
Those groups of neurons learn the relationship between different sounds and the possibility that they go together to predict what might come next.
What word comes next?

AI that predicts text, like the ones that provide the next word in the iPhone’s messaging app or Gmail’s new Smart Compose suggestions that tries to guess what you are writing in an email, also relies on understanding relationships. For these AIs, they learn the correlation between letters, words, and sentences after being trained on millions of documents.

speech.title: How AI learns the worst from us

text.value: The problem with training AI on old documents is that it learns human biases. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase “O bir doktor” into “He is a doctor,” despite “o” being a gender-neutral third-person pronoun. Why? The algorithm just saw more examples of doctors being identified as men and learned that relationship. Google now offers up both a “he” and “she” translation. A recent study shows how this bias is alive and well in humans—just 5 percent of people assume a doctor is a woman, despite making up 44 percent of the profession.

More research into exactly what the brain does might help with dyslexics who struggle to read at speed and are missing the predictive ability. Already, AI-assisted tools like Grammarly are already helping dyslexics fix spelling errors and divining what they meant to write.
